caption: Absolutely loved this museum and wish I had more time. If you like masks and similar art you would love it. The temporary zombie exhibit was great also. I definitely will be back.

One of the best museums in the world. Yes of course it‚Äôs a result of a colonial past, and the pertinent present day critique is why they have 300,000 artefacts stored up and not distributed in museums around the world, BUT, it‚Äôs still one of the best museums in the world and it‚Äôs worth to come Paris, even for a day, just to visit it. Gives a perspective on humanities non western cultural genealogy. The lighting is amazing and the headphone narrative is great too. Actually i should give it a 4 star because there is so much more potential like constant cultural platforms for by the living tribes who are represented through their material culture but‚Ä¶no. Visit it

This is an excellent museum for anyone who is interested in ethnic art and culture. Excellent collection of African masks. I think there are enough signs in English to help people navigate through the permanent collection. On the day I was there it was 95% French nationals and did not feel crowded; and you have time to look into their superb collection. It‚Äôs also a very nice setting with gardens in the middle of the city. Highly recommended.

Beautiful museum! We had the privilege of attending the temporary exposition about Mexico. As a Mexican, I felt very proud of how well everything was displayed and, more importantly, their respect for my culture. Highly recommended.

I recently visited this museum in Paris to see the Mexican exhibit and was thoroughly impressed. The exhibit was beautifully curated, showcasing a diverse range of Mexican art and culture. The pieces on display were both captivating and educational, providing a wonderful insight into Mexican history and traditions. The museum itself was well-maintained and the staff were knowledgeable and friendly. I highly recommend visiting this museum, especially if you have an interest in Mexican art and culture and can catch this exhibit. A truly enriching experience in the heart of Paris.

Grounds are lovely, but don't get distracted from finding the entrance, You can enjoy the grounds and lovely cafe under the museum afterward.  The collection of African and Island art is magnificent, and the ramping entry with a river of languages is soothing and interesting. My only quibble is that many of the displays' descriptions are poorly illuminated as well as in tiny print. This museum is popular with school children; perhaps bring one to have their fresh eyes read the tiny descriptions in the dark.
Still my favorite Musee in town! The team here work their brains out to offer some of the most astonishing and entertaining exhibitions in the world! A billion applauses!
Beautiful, modern museum in the middle of a park. The permanent collection is so stunning and so rich it deserves more than one visit. Well worth the trek to the 7th arrondissement.

A nice museum and a must see, to view artifacts from all over the world. I'm on the fence, especially with African art which should be returned to their rightful owners but these pieces are something to behold and appreciate. With that being said, the design of the museum needs a lot to be desired. It's poorly lit and the there is no structure or cohesion, compared to other museums such as the Louvre or the MET. Still worth a visit and the shop is nice too.

The museum is quite "young", opened in 2006, but highly pro organized space. Impressive. Asia, America, Australia, Africa - all these continents are represented here. I was lucky to participate in a tour guide. Otherwise, it would be hard to navigate.  A lot of information

The museum's significance stems from two key aspects: its distinctive architectural design and its captivating content.  The architectural design seamlessly integrates the building into its surroundings, creating a unique landscape that imparts a sense of entering an environmental oasis in the heart of Paris.  As for the content, which is paramount, it resides in the wealth of artifacts representing the ancient civilizations of peoples from Asia, Oceania, Africa, and the Americas before the era of European colonialism.  The museum showcases finds that were previously unknown, offering visitors a glimpse into the richness and diversity of these cultures.  As a result, visitors are left feeling awestruck and humbled by the greatness and diversity of human civilization.
The infrastructure is well thought for people to rest while visiting the museum, unlike many other museums and chateau in France.

Located near to Pont de Alma and walking distance to Eiffel Tower makes this musee much more interesting and worth the visit! I‚Äôve booking my ticket via online and it‚Äôs worth it and valid for permanent exhibition (Asia, Africa, Oceanic) also for the Mexican which is additional and temporary exhibitions. This museum is very big and I love it because it has so complete facilities and very tidy in terms of placing and maintaining. But for suggestions is more consistent with English caption bit better understanding for tourists.

Absolutely amazing museum! I've never seen such massive collections of arts and cultures from Africa, Asia, Oceania, and the Americas! I definitely recommend visiting this museum as it's free if you are under 25 from EU. I bought the ticket on the day but it's recommended to book in advance. They had a temporary exhibition Mexica about aztecs and excavations around the Templo Mayor, which was mesmerizing as I've never seen anything like it. They projected a short  5 minute movie about Mexica history, which was in French with English subtitles. Unique chance to see up close artefacts never before exhibited in Europe like offerings to the gods, various stone statues, and actual skeletons. Only until Sunday, September 8 2024. All the staff were extremely helpful,  helped me purchase a ticket from the machine and provided me with an english brochure.

Love this museum! Have been here twice. The exhibits are unusual and interesting. Their rotating special exhibit is also good. The Cafe is a great place for lunch and to recharge your batteries.  What's even better -- unlike many museums in Paris, this one is not overrun.  You don't feel like you're racing the rest of humanity to see the exhibits (yes, I'm looking at you, Louvre).  I recommend getting the audio guide, especially if you don't speak French. Although some of the signage is in French and English, the vast majority is not.

I love ethnic art and this place is my favourite museum in Paris. Fantastic architecture, set in lovely gardens, magnolias in flower this month, by the River Seine. There's a long ramp up to the galleries with a waterfall of words in light projected onto the floor. Since I last visited, lots of new exhibits are on show. While you are there, break your visit for lunch at Caf√© Jacques, which has some great food at a reasonable price if you take le formule. Try to miss the school children visits if you can.

Nice museum. Seemed small at first glance, but it's just organized in clever rows, spent 3+ hours here. There's several toilets available inside. Tickets are available online, but there were no queue to the ticket machines offline. Good art, rarely present in other museums.
The museum is so beautiful and the temporary exhibition was great. I will try to return for the permanent exhibition and hope to try the restaurant as well. Love it!

It's one of my favourite museums in Paris. Ideally, book your tickets online as the most probably you'll have to buy them at the machines in front of the museum. I enjoyed the temporary collections. The shop is also nice to get some gifts.

Fantastic. Fascinating. Amazing and diverse exhibits from throughout the world. Do not miss. Permanent exhibits were better than the temporary ones. Excellent curation and display. Must come again to see more.

Lovely museum of anthropology. Perfect to make a trip around the globe üåç different tribes from different ages. Mask, jewelry, tapestry, arms and more... With an exquisite garden to take a sit, rest, read a book üìö perhaps... Remember the 1st Sunday of every month entrance it's free (without reservation)

Very enjoyable museum to visit. The artefacts were displayed and lit beautifully with plenty of information available. Wasn't overwhelming in size with places to sit and rest if desired. Lunch in the cafe was also excellent. Highly recommend.

What a beautiful visit! A lot of enchanting collections from all corners of the world. We went there on Friday afternoon and there was practically no queue. We bought the tickets onsite (12‚Ç¨ each) and found our way to the entrance. Outside was green, cool and full of trees. Inside was nicely ventilated and refreshing for visitors coming in from the hot streets. We were enchanted by the slope entrance way with projections called ‚Äûthe River‚Äú which displayed on the walking surface in a form of meandering rives. These artificial rivers show numerous names (some 15,000) of people who from parts of the collections in the museum. That was our highlight not to mention many special items of fabrics, wood work, stone work, tribal objects to name a few. One can browse around slowly for at least an hour. We were searching for a painting of our Thai friend that was in display in a special exhibition here and were disappointed that it was (naturally) removed long time ago. However, we were lucky enough to have found a nearly last copy in the museum bookshop due to the excellent help of the shop assistant. Thank you so much. All in all we had an enchanting experience here and can recommend the museum wholeheartedly for a visit if you want to experience something different!

The collections from countries on each continent are well displayed. I also saw the special exhibition, and I was very impressed. I recommend places to visit besides the Louvre, Orsay, and Pompidou museums. It has a wonderful exterior.

This museum houses a fantastic collection of world art, featuring Oceana, Africa, Asia, and the Americas, and consists of an impressive number of artifacts. Viewing such an array of artwork side by side, a universal theme emerges that transcends countries or nations. Amplified by the circular and fluid interior design of the museum, one is faced with the reality that we, as human beings, regardless of creed or country, are essentially all the same, with a unifying need for dialogue and expression. This museum highlights the importance of non-Western art and its impact on the world heritage. Well worth a visit and highly recommended!

The permanent collection isn't huge but it has a great selection of global indigenous art. Totally worth a couple hours or more to stroll around. Entry at the afternoon appointment is nice. Fewer people and students.

The Mus√©e du Quai Branly - Jacques Chirac offers a captivating journey through the diverse cultures and artistic expressions of indigenous peoples from around the world. With its striking architectural design and extensive collection of artifacts, the museum provides a thought-provoking exploration of global cultural heritage. Visitors are immersed in a rich tapestry of exhibits, ranging from traditional artworks to contemporary installations, fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of cultural diversity. The museum's commitment to showcasing marginalized voices and promoting cross-cultural dialogue makes it a truly enriching experience for all who visit. Whether you're a seasoned art enthusiast or a curious traveler, the Mus√©e du Quai Branly - Jacques Chirac offers a unique and unforgettable cultural adventure.

My favourite museum. A bubble of peace in the middle of the city. We stopped in November to see the Black Indians and Kimono exhibits. Kinda wish the explanations were all translated to English and not only the curators notes. Many of the captions are only in French :( You might want to book your tickets before dropping by on weekends. We went on Tuesday - no queue at all.

Wow. I walked in without much expectation but after going in, I can see that the museum does have a valuable collection of native art from all parts of the world, like Canada, New Zealand, Africa‚Ä¶etc. The art motif and pattern design involved are thought provoking and really helped explain the fascination of the modern artists, most notably Picasso. It is not to be missed by any artists. Also, for most people who would not have the fortunate to visit so many countries, this museum really help shed light on the art from all over the world. A great equalizer.

The Mus√©e du Quai Branly is a fascinating museum dedicated to indigenous art and cultures from Africa, Asia, Oceania, and the Americas. Its striking architecture, designed by Jean Nouvel, blends beautifully with its lush garden surroundings. Inside, the exhibits are diverse and immersive, showcasing unique artifacts and rich cultural histories. The museum offers a deep, educational experience, making it perfect for those interested in global art and anthropology. With its engaging displays and peaceful atmosphere, it‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone looking to explore the world‚Äôs artistic heritage in Paris.

Always a pleasure this museum is far from old concepts. The garden outside is marvelous and the temporary expositions are always made to think the visitor. Jean Nouvel concept of the museum with organic corridors and a circular visit path are interesting. Maybe I would prefer having more light but i understand that's made for concentrating the attention on the exposition rather than the building itself.

Awesome virtual viewing of museum, thanks for having this ability. Anyone can virtually visit your museum from anywhere within network range of our Earth üåé. My daughter and I were a few hundred meters from it when visiting Paris and didn't know it was there. Went online to reminis and found you. I've been showing and sending link to others

Great architecture and landscape design. I like how the approach is very smooth, and that the benches in the museum is designed with rounded smooth corners that blend into the wooden wall, which creates a warm feeling that echos the river Seine. I saw the V&A Kimono exhibition. It's such a treat! The temporary exhibition place however is a bit small and crowded.
Wonderful Experience. Very well curated and each exhibition was intriguing. One ticket for all (4 at the time) expositions.

The museum and garden are indeed delightful, boasting a beautiful collection of artifacts. However, during my visit, I noticed a few areas that could be improved to enhance the overall experience. Firstly, many signs in the museum are only written in French, which can be challenging for international visitors. Secondly, the audio-guide provided limited information, leaving me craving more insights into the exhibits. Additionally, while there are small screens available, the way the information is presented was not very clear. As a result, the interactivity felt lacking.  I had hoped that the museum would transport me back in time and offer a more immersive experience into different cultures, but I felt somewhat disconnected due to these issues. Despite that, I still believe the museum is worth a visit, especially considering the good price-quality value it offers.
Nice garden and building. If you are interested in indegenous art, it is also interesting inside

Just off the busy streets surrounding the Eiffel Tower, this beautifully designed museum first greets you with a tranquil layout of gardens and seating areas. Even if that's as far as you make it, you've already succeeded!  Inside, for your viewing pleasure, is a well-curated collection of artifacts and art pieces from Africa, Asia, Oceania, and the Americas.  The interior design is quite unique and a fun experience in and of itself.  One nice touch are the floorplan maps found throughout, so you're never lost (or can easily find a specific region).  Be prepared for a low-light environment, intended to preserve the sensitive exhibits.

Hidden gem of a museum. After a disappointing visit to the crowd at the Eiffel Tower, this museum was a breath of fresh air. I got to enjoy a museum which hosts artefacts from all over the world virtually alone. No more than 30 other visitors in the museum the whole visit. I got to see a temporary exhibition about the effects of ayahuasca and psychedelics on creative minds and the work it produces which made my day.
